For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
• The system is best classified as a nearly face-on early/intermediate‐type barred spiral galaxy (SBa–SBb) displaying a well–defined inner pseudo-ring.  
• No obvious secondary nuclei or major tidal distortions are present, so the object appears to be a single galaxy rather than an ongoing major merger.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
• Central nucleus / bulge  
  – Bright, compact, and marginally unresolved at this resolution.  
  – Colour is roughly neutral (blue-white), consistent with a composite of an old bulge population plus a modest level of ongoing nuclear activity; an AGN cannot be ruled out.  

• Stellar bar  
  – A short linear structure, ∼2–3 pixels in length, oriented roughly NNE–SSW (position angle ≈ 20–30° east of north).  
  – The bar terminates where the inner ring/spiral arms begin, typical of resonant bar–ring systems.  

• Inner pseudo-ring / tightly wound spiral arms  
  – Low–surface-brightness, nearly circular feature surrounding the bar/bulge, radius ≈ 3–4× the bulge semi-major axis.  
  – Blue-white colour similar to the nucleus, indicative of current or recent star formation.  
  – Azimuthal light distribution is fairly smooth; individual H II-region knots are not resolved at this depth.  
  – Likely formed by two tightly wound spiral arms that close to form an R′1–type resonance ring.  

• Disk and outer envelope  
  – Faint, diffuse emission extends beyond the ring with no obvious warp or asymmetry, suggesting a low inclination (< 15–20°) and an absence of strong tidal perturbations.  
  – No pronounced dust lanes are visible; any internal extinction is minimal along the line of sight.  

• Environment / line-of-sight objects  
  – A few red, point-like sources in the field are consistent with background galaxies or foreground stars; none show clear interaction signatures with the primary galaxy.  
  – No arc-like, blue features characteristic of strong gravitational lensing are detected.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• The morphology (SB + inner ring) is typical of barred spirals where gas is funneled inward by the bar and accumulates near the inner Lindblad resonance, triggering circumnuclear and ring star formation.  
• The overall blue-white integrated colour implies a significant population of young to intermediate-age stars; combined with the presence of a bar, this suggests secular evolution rather than interaction-driven starbursts.  
• The absence of obvious tidal tails or asymmetries argues against a recent major merger; any past interaction was either minor or sufficiently ancient for the disk to have relaxed.  
• If higher-resolution or spectroscopic data became available, one could test for:  
  – Bar-driven gas inflow via non-circular kinematics.  
  – Star-forming ring diagnostics (e.g., Hα equivalent width, metallicity gradients).  
  – Possible low-luminosity AGN signatures in the nucleus (e.g., narrow [O III], mid-IR excess).

  – Structure: Disk surface brightness is so low that only vestigial, broad spiral segments are visible; no well-defined arms or dust lanes are resolved at this depth/resolution.

  – Point-like, with a saturated core and slight colour fringing; almost certainly a Milky Way star rather than a compact background AGN.  
  – Projected separation from the galaxy centre is ≈6″ eastward; photometrically unrelated but its PSF wings slightly contaminate the galaxy’s eastern side.

• Field Population  
  – Several fainter, redder point sources (likely additional foreground stars) and a few small, red background galaxies are scattered through the frame; none show obvious interaction signatures with the primary galaxy.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  

• Stellar Populations:  The strong colour contrast (yellow bulge vs. blue disk) implies a composite stellar population: an older, metal-rich bulge embedded in a disk hosting ongoing or recent star formation.  The absence of a pronounced bar suggests secular evolution has been mild, or the bar is below the resolution limit.

• Environment / Interactions:  No tidal tails, shells, or asymmetries are apparent, arguing against a recent major interaction.  The smooth outer isophotes also disfavour strong ram-pressure stripping or harassment.  The galaxy therefore appears to be an isolated or weakly interacting field system.

• Observational Caveats:  
  – The very low surface brightness of the disk means deeper imaging could reveal additional spiral structure or faint outer rings.  
  – Photometry on the eastern side should account for scattered light from the bright foreground star.  
  – Spectroscopic follow-up would pin down the bulge/disk kinematics and confirm whether the nucleus hosts a weak AGN (no optical point source or colour excess is evident here).

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
The dominant object at the frame centre is a luminous, smooth, yellow‐orange early-type system consistent with a giant elliptical (likely the BCG of a small group/poor cluster).  A number of fainter companions and projected objects populate the field, including:  
• A compact, point-spread-function (PSF) dominated cyan source at lower-left (foreground star).  
• A small, highly elongated blue–green source immediately east of the BCG.  
• A moderately inclined, yellow disc/spiral galaxy on the eastern edge of the cut-out.  
• Several still fainter, red or blue background galaxies scattered through the field.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
a) Brightest central galaxy (BCG/elliptical)  
   • Morphology: Purely elliptical profile with no discernible spiral structure; light distribution is centrally concentrated and falls off smoothly with radius.  
   • Colour: Yellow–orange (g-r ≳ 0.8 from the composite), indicating an old, metal-rich stellar population and little ongoing star formation.  
   • Halo: A diffuse, low-surface-brightness envelope extends ≥2–3 R_e, suggestive of an intracluster-light component.  
   • Possible lensing signature: A very faint, slightly curved, blue arclet just east of the galaxy (below the elongated companion) is plausibly a strongly-lensed background source, although deeper imaging would be required for confirmation.

b) Blue–green elongated source (immediately east of BCG)  
   • Morphology: Axial ratio ≲0.3, length ≈3″, PA ≈20° (N through E). Could be either (i) a lensed image of a background galaxy or (ii) a star-forming, edge-on disc satellite.  
   • Colour: Pronounced [g + r] excess relative to i, consistent with strong emission lines or young stellar population.  
   • Interaction: No obvious tidal bridge to the BCG, but projected separation is <1″ so dynamical friction merger timescale is short if physically associated.

c) Western/LH cyan point source  
   • PSF width: ≲1.5 pixels; radially symmetric first Airy ring visible.  
   • Spectrum is likely dominated by Milky-Way stellar continuum; no host halo detected → foreground star.

d) Eastern yellow disc galaxy  
   • Morphology: Inclination ≈50°, discernible bulge plus faint outer disc; a single asymmetric arm hints at minor tidal disturbance.  
   • Colour: Bulge is yellow; disc shows subtly bluer outskirts, implying moderate, spatially confined star formation.

e) Additional faint objects  
   • Several red, compact galaxies (likely early-type cluster members) appear to trace a loose concentration around the BCG, strengthening the group/cluster interpretation.  
   • A small, thin red streak north of the BCG is an edge-on background disc.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Environment: The morphology, colour, and extended halo of the central elliptical together with the density of red companions suggest a low-richness cluster at z ≈0.2–0.4.  
• Lensing prospects: If the curved blue feature is confirmed to be an arc, the BCG’s velocity dispersion would be of order σ ≈ 250–300 km s⁻¹, consistent with its luminosity. Multi-band or spectroscopy would test this.  
• Evolutionary state: The lack of strong shells or tidal tails around the BCG argues that any major merger activity ended ≥1–2 Gyr ago; current assembly is likely minor (dry accretion of satellites).  
• Star-formation diagnostics: Only the cyan/green elongated object and outer disc of the eastern spiral exhibit colours consistent with on-going star formation; the majority of the luminous mass in the field is quiescent.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
The field is dominated by a close, two–component interacting/merging system.  Both components show disk-like light distributions rather than smooth de Vaucouleurs profiles, implying that the progenitors are late-type (spiral/S0) galaxies rather than giant ellipticals.  Their projected separation is of order a single optical half-light radius (i.e., they overlap), placing the pair in an advanced pre-coalescence stage of a major merger.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  

a. Blue, compact component (south-west side)  
• Colour: markedly blue–white continuum, consistent with a substantial young stellar population and/or an unobscured AGN power-law contribution.  
• Morphology: centrally-peaked, nearly point-like nucleus enveloped by a faint, asymmetric envelope.  The absence of obvious spiral structure suggests the original disk has been tidally disturbed.  
• Star formation / AGN: the luminosity concentration and very blue colour raise the possibility of either a circumnuclear starburst or a Type 1/2 AGN. No clear jet or narrow-line cone is visible at this resolution.

b. Yellow-orange, elongated component (north-east side)  
• Colour: redder (g–r ≳ 0.7) than its companion, indicative of an older stellar population and/or larger internal dust column.  
• Morphology: an edge-on or moderately inclined stellar disk with a major-to-minor axis ratio ≈ 4:1.  The surface brightness profile is smooth, lacking a prominent bulge; the disk appears truncated on the side closest to the blue companion, suggesting stripping.  
• Dust lane: a subtle, darker mid-plane strip is visible, implying an internal dusty disk viewed close to edge-on.

c. Bridge / overlap region  
• A low-surface-brightness, triangular bridge joins the two galaxies, most obvious in the green–red channels.  This stellar debris stream runs roughly NW–SE and is the clearest sign of ongoing tidal interaction.  
• The bridge contains both blue knots and diffuse red light, pointing to mixed stellar ages produced by triggered star formation plus older disk stars pulled out of the progenitors.

d. Tidal debris & outer envelope  
• Faint, diffuse light extends beyond each galaxy, especially south of the blue component, suggestive of tidal tails.  The tails are patchy rather than coherent grand-design arcs, signalling either projection effects or an early stage of tidal-tail development.  
• No clear counter-tail is detected to the north, plausibly because of surface-brightness limits or line-of-sight overlap with the redder disk.

e. Fore-/background sources  
• Two red, unresolved points north of the system (one directly north, one north-east) are consistent with background galaxies at higher redshift; no PSF wings indicative of foreground stars are seen.  
• No lensing features (arc segments, multiple images) are apparent; the system’s mass and projected geometry are insufficient to generate strong lensing signatures at this resolution.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Interaction stage: the presence of a stellar bridge and incipient tidal tails without a single, common envelope implies the pair is between first pericentre and final coalescence (~0.3–0.6 Gyr after first passage in typical merger simulations).  
• Colour dichotomy: the blue component may be experiencing a merger-induced starburst (or harbour an unobscured AGN), while the redder disk has either exhausted its gas or is more effectively dust-enshrouded.  
• Future evolution: dynamical friction will probably drive the nuclei together, producing a remnant with a disturbed, thick disk or nascent bulge and an enhanced central starburst/AGN phase before relaxing into an early-type morphology.  
• Scaling: without spectroscopic redshift the physical scale is undetermined, but if the galaxies are L* systems (MB ≈ –20.5) the projected separation is likely 5–15 kpc and the tidal features extend ≥10 kpc.  
• Scientific utility: the system is a useful laboratory for studying (i) colour-dependent tidal stripping, (ii) disk heating and disruption, and (iii) triggered central activity in unequal-colour mergers.

Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
• The dominant object is a nearly perfectly edge-on, disc-dominated system.  
• The radial light profile shows a modest central concentration but no pronounced spheroid, placing the system morphologically in the range S0–Sa (an early-type spiral or lenticular).  
• The extreme axial ratio (>15:1 in the displayed cut-out) and the absence of conspicuous flaring or tidal distortion indicate an undisturbed, rotationally–supported stellar disc.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
a) Stellar Disc  
   – Geometry: razor-thin mid-plane, uniform thickness over most of the visible radius; vertical scale height appears roughly constant, with no obvious warp or flare.  
   – Extent: the disc spans the full frame (~15″ in the SDSS colour composite), tapering smoothly at both ends.  
   – Surface-brightness profile: exponential wings with a slight ‘boxy’ central isophote, typical of an early-type disc with a thin+thick component.  
   – Colour: globally yellow-orange (g–r ≃ 0.7–0.8 by eye), indicative of an evolved, predominantly K-type stellar population; very little blue light, hence low current star formation.

b) Central Bulge / Pseudobulge  
   – A luminous, slightly thicker region is visible within ±3″ of the mid-plane centre.  
   – The bulge is small relative to the total disc length (B/D ≲ 0.2), has the same colour as the disc, and shows no strong point source, arguing against a dominant classical bulge or bright AGN.  
   – Isophotes are almost cylindrical, suggestive of a pseudobulge formed via secular evolution rather than a merger-built classical bulge.

c) Dust Content  
   – No conspicuous dust lane seen along the mid-plane; any absorption features are below the resolution/noise level of the image.  
   – The absence of a sharp dust lane is consistent with a gas-poor S0 or an Sa with low molecular/atomic gas surface density.

d) Star-forming Knots / H II Complexes  
   – None detectable in this broadband image; the disc light is smooth with no blue clumps.

e) External or Foreground Objects  
   – A sub-arcsecond, green-tinted point ~2″ below the mid-plane (slightly south of centre) is likely a foreground Milky-Way star or a hot pixel; it is unresolved and colour-shifted relative to the galaxy.  
   – Several very faint, red and blue background galaxies are scattered in the field but do not interact with the main galaxy.

f) Non-detection of Additional Phenomena  
   – No tidal tails, shells, or streams; no obvious interaction partner.  
   – No gravitational lensing features; no radio-jet or AGN signature in the optical image.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• The uniformly old stellar colours and lack of dust suggest the system has exhausted or lost most of its cold gas—typical of field S0s or “quenched” early spirals.  
• The clean edge-on orientation makes the galaxy a good candidate for vertical stellar-population or dynamical scale-height studies.  
• If confirmed as an S0, the galaxy’s thinness argues for secular disc fading rather than a violent merger origin; any thick disc component must be relatively faint.  
• Deep, high-S/N imaging or IFU spectroscopy could test for:  
  – a faint residual star-forming layer (via H α or [O II]);  
  – a rotationally supported vs. dispersion-dominated bulge;  
  – possible low-level AGN activity obscured in the optical but detectable in IR/X-ray.  
• In large surveys (e.g., SDSS), galaxies of this type contribute to the red sequence and are often used to probe environmental quenching and morphological transformation mechanisms.

judge_results.judge_prompt:
You are an expert astronomer who will classify a galaxy by following the same decision tree structure used by citizen scientists in Galaxy Zoo.

You will be given a galaxy description and must make decisions following this exact decision tree structure:

**STEP 1: Overall Shape (Required)**
- smooth: Galaxy appears smooth and featureless with no obvious structure
- featured-or-disk: Galaxy shows clear structure like spiral arms, bars, or disk features  
- artifact: Image appears to be a star, artifact, or defect rather than a galaxy

**STEP 2: Follow the appropriate branch based on Step 1**

**If SMOOTH:**
- Determine roundness: round, in-between, cigar-shaped, or not-mentioned

**If FEATURED-OR-DISK:**
- Determine if edge-on: edge-on-yes, edge-on-no, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-yes:**
- Determine bulge shape: boxy, none, rounded, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-no:**
- Determine if has spiral arms: has-spiral-arms-yes, has-spiral-arms-no, or not-mentioned
- If has spiral arms:
  - Determine spiral winding: tight, medium, loose, or not-mentioned
  - Determine arm count: 1, 2, 3, 4, more-than-4, cant-tell, or not-mentioned
- For all non-edge-on galaxies (regardless of spiral arms):
  - Determine bar strength: strong, weak, no, or not-mentioned
  - Determine bulge size: dominant, large, moderate, small, none, or not-mentioned

**STEP 3: Merging Status (ONLY for smooth and featured-or-disk galaxies, NOT artifacts)**
- none: No signs of disturbance or interaction
- minor-disturbance: Small distortions or asymmetries
- major-disturbance: Significant warping, tidal features, or distortions
- merger: Clear signs of ongoing merger or recent collision
- not-mentioned: The description does not mention anything about merging or disturbance

**IMPORTANT INSTRUCTIONS:**
- Base your decisions ONLY on what you can observe in the description
- **Use "not-mentioned" for any field where the description does not provide sufficient information to make a determination**
- Follow the decision tree logic - only fill out fields that are relevant for your path
- Be definitive in your choices when information is available
- **Merging status is ONLY asked for smooth and featured-or-disk galaxies, NOT for artifacts**
- If the description is unclear about a specific feature, choose "not-mentioned" rather than guessing

**GALAXY DESCRIPTION:**
1. Overall Morphology  
• The dominant object is a nearly perfectly edge-on, disc-dominated system.  
• The radial light profile shows a modest central concentration but no pronounced spheroid, placing the system morphologically in the range S0–Sa (an early-type spiral or lenticular).  
• The extreme axial ratio (>15:1 in the displayed cut-out) and the absence of conspicuous flaring or tidal distortion indicate an undisturbed, rotationally–supported stellar disc.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
a) Stellar Disc  
   – Geometry: razor-thin mid-plane, uniform thickness over most of the visible radius; vertical scale height appears roughly constant, with no obvious warp or flare.  
   – Extent: the disc spans the full frame (~15″ in the SDSS colour composite), tapering smoothly at both ends.  
   – Surface-brightness profile: exponential wings with a slight ‘boxy’ central isophote, typical of an early-type disc with a thin+thick component.  
   – Colour: globally yellow-orange (g–r ≃ 0.7–0.8 by eye), indicative of an evolved, predominantly K-type stellar population; very little blue light, hence low current star formation.

b) Central Bulge / Pseudobulge  
   – A luminous, slightly thicker region is visible within ±3″ of the mid-plane centre.  
   – The bulge is small relative to the total disc length (B/D ≲ 0.2), has the same colour as the disc, and shows no strong point source, arguing against a dominant classical bulge or bright AGN.  
   – Isophotes are almost cylindrical, suggestive of a pseudobulge formed via secular evolution rather than a merger-built classical bulge.

c) Dust Content  
   – No conspicuous dust lane seen along the mid-plane; any absorption features are below the resolution/noise level of the image.  
   – The absence of a sharp dust lane is consistent with a gas-poor S0 or an Sa with low molecular/atomic gas surface density.

d) Star-forming Knots / H II Complexes  
   – None detectable in this broadband image; the disc light is smooth with no blue clumps.

e) External or Foreground Objects  
   – A sub-arcsecond, green-tinted point ~2″ below the mid-plane (slightly south of centre) is likely a foreground Milky-Way star or a hot pixel; it is unresolved and colour-shifted relative to the galaxy.  
   – Several very faint, red and blue background galaxies are scattered in the field but do not interact with the main galaxy.

f) Non-detection of Additional Phenomena  
   – No tidal tails, shells, or streams; no obvious interaction partner.  
   – No gravitational lensing features; no radio-jet or AGN signature in the optical image.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• The uniformly old stellar colours and lack of dust suggest the system has exhausted or lost most of its cold gas—typical of field S0s or “quenched” early spirals.  
• The clean edge-on orientation makes the galaxy a good candidate for vertical stellar-population or dynamical scale-height studies.  
• If confirmed as an S0, the galaxy’s thinness argues for secular disc fading rather than a violent merger origin; any thick disc component must be relatively faint.  
• Deep, high-S/N imaging or IFU spectroscopy could test for:  
  – a faint residual star-forming layer (via H α or [O II]);  
  – a rotationally supported vs. dispersion-dominated bulge;  
  – possible low-level AGN activity obscured in the optical but detectable in IR/X-ray.  
• In large surveys (e.g., SDSS), galaxies of this type contribute to the red sequence and are often used to probe environmental quenching and morphological transformation mechanisms.

Classify this galaxy by following the decision tree structure above.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
The dominant source is a face-on, ring-bearing system whose light is divided into (i) a compact, spheroidal core and (ii) a broad, nearly circular outer ring.  In the de Vaucouleurs notation it would be classified something like (R)SA0^0/Hoag-type; alternatively it can be discussed as a classical collisional/radial-resonance ring galaxy.  No obvious large-scale spiral structure, bar, or tidal distortion is visible, and the symmetry of the ring suggests the galaxy is viewed close to 0° inclination.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  

a. Central Core / Bulge  
• Morphology: Point-like to very compact, round, with a smooth light profile.  
• Colour: Yellow-white, consistent with an older, metal-rich stellar population (Sa/S0 bulge or E-type core).  
• Extent: Angular diameter ≈ 1/3 that of the ring (exact metrics depend on plate scale).  
• Possible AGN: No obvious blue point source or jet‐like features; any AGN activity would be low-lumin-osity or obscured in this stretch.

b. Detached Outer Ring  
• Morphology: Continuous, nearly circular annulus; inner edge is sharply defined, outer edge gradually fades into the background sky.  
• Width: Broad (comparable to the radius of the central core), suggesting a substantial radial extent of star-forming material.  
• Colour: Bluish-cyan, indicating a population dominated by young, massive stars (OB associations) and/or strong nebular line emission (e.g. Hα+[O III]) within broadband filters.  
• Surface brightness: Low to moderate; uniformly smooth with no well-resolved condensations or H II-region clumps at the current resolution.  
• Orientation: Concentric with the core; no visible twist or lopsidedness.

c. Inter-ring Gap  
• A relatively dark annulus separates the core from the outer ring.  This “forbidden” zone is typical of resonant or collisional rings where gas has been radially displaced and/or rapidly converted to stars.

d. Fore-/Background Objects  
• Southeast of the ring (lower right) is an orange, slightly elongated source; colour and morphology are consistent with a distant, passive galaxy or a highly reddened star.  
• Northwest (upper left) is a faint, unresolved, white point — almost certainly a Galactic foreground star.  
• No obvious tidal debris, plumes, shells, or secondary nuclei are present.

e. Lensing vs. Stellar Ring Discussion  
• The combination of a yellow spheroidal core + blue, axisymmetric, low-surface-brightness ring is typical of Hoag-type stellar rings rather than of gravitational-lensing Einstein rings (which often show multiple, clumpy images rather than a smooth, monotonic surface-brightness profile).  No counter-images or mirrored sub-structure is apparent, making a lensing interpretation disfavoured.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  

• Formation Scenarios  
  – Collisional Ring: A near head-on passage of a small companion through an early-type disk could have driven a radially propagating density wave, producing the observed ring.  
  – Resonance Ring: A dynamically dissolved or very weak bar could trap gas at the outer Lindblad resonance; the absence of an obvious bar might imply bar dissolution after ring formation.  
  – Polar Ring is unlikely; the ring lies in the same plane as the core’s isophotes rather than in an orthogonal geometry.  

• Stellar Populations & Gas Content  
  – Core likely dominated by ≥Gyr-old stars with little current star formation.  
  – Ring should exhibit strong nebular emission and UV excess; follow-up narrow-band/H-α imaging or integral-field spectroscopy would quantify SFR, metallicity gradients, and kinematics.  

• Dynamics & Kinematics  
  – Long-slit or IFU data could confirm fast rotation in the ring and a lower-dispersion, pressure-supported core, placing constraints on the collisional or secular origin scenario.  
  – A symmetric velocity field would support a resonance ring; a strong radial expansion component would favour a collisional interpretation.  

• Environmental Notes  
  – No obvious interaction partner is visible in the immediate vicinity (the orange object is projected ∼1 ring diameter away and appears too small to have produced a strong head-on collision today).  
  – Deep imaging could search for faint tidal streams or remnants of the intruder galaxy that may have triggered ring formation.  

In summary, the image shows a prototypical ring galaxy with a quiescent central spheroid and a star-forming outer ring, most plausibly generated by either a past, near-central collision or by secular resonance processes within an early-type disk.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
• Dominant object: a nearly face-on, grand-design spiral galaxy.  
• Probable Hubble type: Sbc – SBbc.  The spiral arms are moderately wound and symmetric; a very weak central bar or oval distortion is plausible but not unambiguously resolved at this spatial resolution.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  

a) Bulge / Nuclear region  
   – Bright, centrally-concentrated, yellow–orange continuum emission indicative of an old, metal-rich stellar population.  
   – Point-spread function is smooth with no obvious unresolved nuclear point source; if an AGN is present it is low-luminosity or heavily obscured relative to the stellar background.

b) Bar / Inner oval (tentative)  
   – A slight elongation of the inner isophotes suggests a short bar or oval (position angle ≈ 20–30° counter-clockwise from the horizontal in the current frame).  
   – Length ≲ 0.3 × optical radius; no strong offset dust lanes typical of strong bars are seen, consistent with a weak (SAB) classification.

c) Spiral arm system  
   – Two principal arms emerge approximately 180° apart from the ends of the inner oval, giving the classic “grand-design” appearance.  
   – Arms remain coherent through ≈ 360° in azimuth, bifurcating into secondary, flocculent segments beyond ≈ 0.8 × R25.  
   – Integrated arm colour is blue, punctuated by numerous compact, high-surface-brightness knots (H II regions / OB associations), signifying ongoing massive star formation.  
   – Low-contrast, filamentary dust lanes are seen on the concave (inner) side of each arm, producing mottled extinction against the smoother disk light.

d) Disk & outer structure  
   – The stellar disk is azimuthally symmetric with no detectable warps or lopsidedness above the noise floor, suggesting the system is dynamically relaxed.  
   – No extended tidal tails, shells or plumes are present; interaction-driven perturbations, if any, are currently minor.

e) Foreground / background objects  
   – Several unresolved point sources with diffraction-dominated PSFs lie in the field.  The brightest (east of the nucleus) is most likely a foreground Milky Way star; its colour and size differ markedly from the diffuse extragalactic sources.  
   – A few faint, red, nearly pointlike objects north-east of the disk are probable background galaxies; none exhibit distortions or alignments consistent with strong lensing by the main spiral.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Stellar population gradient: the yellow bulge and blue arms imply a classical age/metallicity radial gradient typical of late-type spirals, with active star formation (timescales ≲ 10 Myr) confined to the spiral density-wave pattern.  
• Dynamical state: the arms’ symmetry, absence of tidal debris, and lack of disk truncation suggest an isolated or only weakly perturbed system; any recent interactions were likely low-mass minor mergers or fly-bys.  
• Bar secular evolution: if the weak bar is real, it may be an early-stage or dissolving structure, consistent with modest gas inflow and limited bar-driven central star formation.  
• Central activity: without a clear unresolved nucleus or strong non-stellar continuum, the data favour a quiescent super-massive black hole, although deeper, higher-resolution imaging or spectroscopy would be required to rule out a LINER/Seyfert nucleus.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
• The system is dominated by a bright, nearly round central component surrounded by a well-defined, almost circular annulus.  
• The global appearance is that of a face-on “ring galaxy” or an S0/Sa disk with a resonance ring; an alternative (though less certain) interpretation is a strong-lensing (Einstein-ring) configuration in which a foreground spheroidal galaxy lenses a background source.  
• No obvious large-scale bar, grand-design spiral arms, or extended tidal debris are visible at the depth of the image.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
a) Central core / bulge  
   – High surface-brightness, yellow-white, and point-symmetric.  
   – Colour and smoothness are consistent with an old, metal-rich stellar population (typical of an early-type bulge or an isolated lensing galaxy).  
   – No obvious dust lanes; no strong colour gradients within the core.  

b) Annular structure (“ring”)  
   – Radius ≈ 2–3× that of the light-weighted half-radius of the core; ellipticity <0.1, implying a viewing angle close to face-on.  
   – Surface brightness is low and patchy: segments of slightly enhanced flux are seen at ≈3 o’clock and ≈9 o’clock position angles.  
   – Overall colour is modestly bluer than the core, suggesting a younger/intermediate stellar population or, in a lensing scenario, a star-forming background galaxy.  
   – No coherent spiral arm pattern or radial spokes are resolved; the ring appears detached from the core by a subtle gap of lower surface brightness.  

c) Compact knots on the ring’s inner edge  
   – Blue knot (PA ≈ 90°): point-like, highest contrast against the ring; could be (i) a luminous H II region / OB association, (ii) a background lensed image, or (iii) a chance-aligned foreground star.  
   – Orange-red knot (PA ≈ 270°): similarly compact but redder; colour difference argues against being mirror-image lensed components of the same source, but differential magnification of separate star-forming regions in a background galaxy remains possible.  
   – Both sources are unresolved at this resolution, supporting the interpretation of either very compact H II regions or point-like foreground/background objects.  

d) Surrounding field  
   – No obvious interacting companion within the frame; background is sparsely populated with faint galaxies and field stars.  
   – No large-scale tidal tails, plumes, or shell structures detected.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Ring-galaxy interpretation: The morphology is reminiscent of Hoag-type or collisional ring systems where a density wave, triggered by a head-on encounter, propagates outward and compresses gas into a star-forming ring. The central spheroid would be the pre-existing bulge, and the colour contrast (yellow core vs. slightly bluer ring) is consistent with a rejuvenated star-forming annulus overlying an older stellar population. Follow-up long-slit or IFU spectroscopy could test for an outwardly expanding velocity field and search for H α/ [O II] emission in the ring.  

• Lensing interpretation: The clean, circular symmetry, coupled with two colour-distinct compact sources at roughly opposite position angles, can also arise in strong gravitational lensing. A background, knotty star-forming galaxy could be imaged into an extended Einstein ring plus multiple compact images. Spectroscopic redshifts would discriminate: identical redshifts for core and ring ⇒ ring galaxy; different redshifts ⇒ lens. High-resolution imaging (e.g. HST, AO) could reveal the fine sub-arcsecond morphology characteristic of lensing (e.g. multiple mirrored sub-structures along the ring).  

• Photometric diagnostics: The nucleus-to-ring colour index, ring surface-brightness profile, and any detectable radial colour gradient across the gap would further constrain stellar populations vs. lensing origin.  

• Environmental notes: Absence of obvious tidal debris or a plausible intruder galaxy disfavors a recent major collision but does not preclude an older interaction or a low-surface-brightness perturber.  

In summary, the object is best described as a face-on ring-bearing system with a luminous central spheroid and two compact knots on the ring. The data are consistent with either (i) an S0/early-type disk hosting a resonant or collisional star-forming ring or (ii) a strong-lensing configuration producing an Einstein ring. Definitive classification requires spectroscopy and higher-resolution imaging.

judge_results.judge_prompt:
You are an expert astronomer who will classify a galaxy by following the same decision tree structure used by citizen scientists in Galaxy Zoo.

You will be given a galaxy description and must make decisions following this exact decision tree structure:

**STEP 1: Overall Shape (Required)**
- smooth: Galaxy appears smooth and featureless with no obvious structure
- featured-or-disk: Galaxy shows clear structure like spiral arms, bars, or disk features  
- artifact: Image appears to be a star, artifact, or defect rather than a galaxy

**STEP 2: Follow the appropriate branch based on Step 1**

**If SMOOTH:**
- Determine roundness: round, in-between, cigar-shaped, or not-mentioned

**If FEATURED-OR-DISK:**
- Determine if edge-on: edge-on-yes, edge-on-no, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-yes:**
- Determine bulge shape: boxy, none, rounded, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-no:**
- Determine if has spiral arms: has-spiral-arms-yes, has-spiral-arms-no, or not-mentioned
- If has spiral arms:
  - Determine spiral winding: tight, medium, loose, or not-mentioned
  - Determine arm count: 1, 2, 3, 4, more-than-4, cant-tell, or not-mentioned
- For all non-edge-on galaxies (regardless of spiral arms):
  - Determine bar strength: strong, weak, no, or not-mentioned
  - Determine bulge size: dominant, large, moderate, small, none, or not-mentioned

**STEP 3: Merging Status (ONLY for smooth and featured-or-disk galaxies, NOT artifacts)**
- none: No signs of disturbance or interaction
- minor-disturbance: Small distortions or asymmetries
- major-disturbance: Significant warping, tidal features, or distortions
- merger: Clear signs of ongoing merger or recent collision
- not-mentioned: The description does not mention anything about merging or disturbance

**IMPORTANT INSTRUCTIONS:**
- Base your decisions ONLY on what you can observe in the description
- **Use "not-mentioned" for any field where the description does not provide sufficient information to make a determination**
- Follow the decision tree logic - only fill out fields that are relevant for your path
- Be definitive in your choices when information is available
- **Merging status is ONLY asked for smooth and featured-or-disk galaxies, NOT for artifacts**
- If the description is unclear about a specific feature, choose "not-mentioned" rather than guessing

**GALAXY DESCRIPTION:**
1. Overall Morphology  
• The system is dominated by a bright, nearly round central component surrounded by a well-defined, almost circular annulus.  
• The global appearance is that of a face-on “ring galaxy” or an S0/Sa disk with a resonance ring; an alternative (though less certain) interpretation is a strong-lensing (Einstein-ring) configuration in which a foreground spheroidal galaxy lenses a background source.  
• No obvious large-scale bar, grand-design spiral arms, or extended tidal debris are visible at the depth of the image.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
a) Central core / bulge  
   – High surface-brightness, yellow-white, and point-symmetric.  
   – Colour and smoothness are consistent with an old, metal-rich stellar population (typical of an early-type bulge or an isolated lensing galaxy).  
   – No obvious dust lanes; no strong colour gradients within the core.  

b) Annular structure (“ring”)  
   – Radius ≈ 2–3× that of the light-weighted half-radius of the core; ellipticity <0.1, implying a viewing angle close to face-on.  
   – Surface brightness is low and patchy: segments of slightly enhanced flux are seen at ≈3 o’clock and ≈9 o’clock position angles.  
   – Overall colour is modestly bluer than the core, suggesting a younger/intermediate stellar population or, in a lensing scenario, a star-forming background galaxy.  
   – No coherent spiral arm pattern or radial spokes are resolved; the ring appears detached from the core by a subtle gap of lower surface brightness.  

c) Compact knots on the ring’s inner edge  
   – Blue knot (PA ≈ 90°): point-like, highest contrast against the ring; could be (i) a luminous H II region / OB association, (ii) a background lensed image, or (iii) a chance-aligned foreground star.  
   – Orange-red knot (PA ≈ 270°): similarly compact but redder; colour difference argues against being mirror-image lensed components of the same source, but differential magnification of separate star-forming regions in a background galaxy remains possible.  
   – Both sources are unresolved at this resolution, supporting the interpretation of either very compact H II regions or point-like foreground/background objects.  

d) Surrounding field  
   – No obvious interacting companion within the frame; background is sparsely populated with faint galaxies and field stars.  
   – No large-scale tidal tails, plumes, or shell structures detected.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Ring-galaxy interpretation: The morphology is reminiscent of Hoag-type or collisional ring systems where a density wave, triggered by a head-on encounter, propagates outward and compresses gas into a star-forming ring. The central spheroid would be the pre-existing bulge, and the colour contrast (yellow core vs. slightly bluer ring) is consistent with a rejuvenated star-forming annulus overlying an older stellar population. Follow-up long-slit or IFU spectroscopy could test for an outwardly expanding velocity field and search for H α/ [O II] emission in the ring.  

• Lensing interpretation: The clean, circular symmetry, coupled with two colour-distinct compact sources at roughly opposite position angles, can also arise in strong gravitational lensing. A background, knotty star-forming galaxy could be imaged into an extended Einstein ring plus multiple compact images. Spectroscopic redshifts would discriminate: identical redshifts for core and ring ⇒ ring galaxy; different redshifts ⇒ lens. High-resolution imaging (e.g. HST, AO) could reveal the fine sub-arcsecond morphology characteristic of lensing (e.g. multiple mirrored sub-structures along the ring).  

• Photometric diagnostics: The nucleus-to-ring colour index, ring surface-brightness profile, and any detectable radial colour gradient across the gap would further constrain stellar populations vs. lensing origin.  

• Environmental notes: Absence of obvious tidal debris or a plausible intruder galaxy disfavors a recent major collision but does not preclude an older interaction or a low-surface-brightness perturber.  

In summary, the object is best described as a face-on ring-bearing system with a luminous central spheroid and two compact knots on the ring. The data are consistent with either (i) an S0/early-type disk hosting a resonant or collisional star-forming ring or (ii) a strong-lensing configuration producing an Einstein ring. Definitive classification requires spectroscopy and higher-resolution imaging.

Classify this galaxy by following the decision tree structure above.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
• The principal object is a nearly face-on disk galaxy exhibiting clear spiral structure.  
• Spiral pitch angle is modest and the arms almost close into a ring, suggesting an early- to intermediate-type unbarred spiral, SA(r)ab in de Vaucouleurs notation (or S0/a–Sb in Hubble terms).  
• No obvious secondary nucleus or companion inside the optical disk; the system appears dynamically undisturbed at the current depth.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
• Bulge – Bright, centrally concentrated, round and yellow, dominating the inner ≈2–3″; smooth profile with no point-like AGN signature.  
• Spiral arms / pseudo-ring – Two main, relatively low-contrast arms emerging close to the bulge, wrapping ≳300° and blending into a diffuse outer ring. Arms display patchy blue knots (ongoing star formation) and faint internal dust absorption but no grand-design dust lanes.  
• Bar – No elongated bar is detectable; the arms begin quasi-axi-symmetrically from the bulge perimeter. If a bar exists it is weaker than the image resolution/contrast.  
• Dust – Mild, filamentary reddening inside the inner arm segments; no large-scale prominent dust lanes.  
• Star-forming regions – Discrete, compact blue clumps along the arms, spatially correlated with the bluer segments of the pseudo-ring.  
• Fore-/background sources – Several foreground Milky Way stars (orange or blue point sources with PSF wings) and faint background galaxies surround the target; none show tidal interaction with the main disk.  
• Artifact – A thin, straight, bright green streak cutting one arm is a single-filter cosmic-ray/satellite trail; it is not astrophysical.  
• No tidal tails, shells, bridges, or lensing arcs are evident at the current image depth.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Colour gradient (yellow bulge → slightly bluer disk) is consistent with an older, metal-rich bulge population and younger, moderately star-forming disk.  
• The nearly complete outer arm suggests a resonance ring; such structures often form at the outer Lindblad resonance of a (possibly weak or dissolved) bar or oval potential.  
• Symmetric morphology and absence of tidal debris argue against any strong recent interaction; secular evolution likely dominates.  
• The resolved nucleus and lack of point-source saturation indicate no luminous AGN; any central activity would be of low radiative output.  
• At typical SDSS depths the surface-brightness profile and colour imply a redshift of order z ≈ 0.05–0.1 (subject to spectroscopic confirmation).  
In sum, the object is a face-on, early-type, non-barred spiral with a faint resonance ring, modest current star formation, and no signs of recent merger activity.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
• The system is best interpreted as an interacting / merging pair.  
  – A red–orange, more luminous component with an elongated profile dominates the optical light.  
  – A bluer, slightly fainter condensation is projected just south-east of the red core and is embedded in the same diffuse envelope.  
  – The common halo is moderately flattened (major axis ≈ E–W), suggesting at least one disk galaxy is involved.  
  – No clean two-armed spiral pattern or smooth r1/4 profile is visible, reinforcing the “disturbed/merger” classification rather than a normal spiral or elliptical.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
a. Dual‐nuclear structure  
   • Red/Yellow nucleus: compact, centrally peaked, FWHM only marginally larger than the local PSF → old, metal-rich stars and/or an obscured AGN.  
   • Blue nucleus/knots: ∼1–2 PSF widths south of the red core, noticeably bluer (u–r ≲ 1). Likely the core of a gas-rich companion or a starburst knot created during first passage.  

b. Elongated inner body / putative bar or disk  
   • Symmetric light plateau along PA ≈ 80° over ≈2–3 kpc (for z≈0.1 scaling) around the red nucleus.  
   • Colours intermediate between the two nuclei, consistent with a bar or tidally heated inner disk.  

c. Star-forming regions  
   • The bluish component and its surrounding faint haze exhibit colour gradients characteristic of OB-rich populations and H II complexes.  
   • No discrete spiral arms are resolved, but patchy, knotty light suggests widespread triggered SF.  

d. Tidal debris / disturbance  
   • Low-surface-brightness wings extend a few PSF widths both east and west, but are not radially symmetric; these are candidate tidal tails or bridges.  
   • No clear shell structure (expected for E+E mergers) is present, supporting a disk-involved collision scenario.  

e. Dust lanes  
   • A slight asymmetry in colour across the mid-plane hints at dust attenuation, but the spatial resolution is insufficient to isolate narrow dust filaments.  

f. Fore-/background objects  
   • Two red, point-like sources south-west of the main system are consistent with unrelated background galaxies or faint M-dwarf stars; they do not distort the main light distribution.  
   • No arc-like features or multiple imaging indicative of strong gravitational lensing are seen.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Interaction stage: Projected nuclear separation of only a few hundred parsecs to a few kiloparsecs (depending on distance) puts the system in the mid-to-late Toomre sequence (pre-coalescence, Stage II–III).  
• Star-formation & IR output: The colour contrast (old red core + blue SF regions) suggests a moderate-to-high specific SFR; the system could qualify as a LIRG at modest redshift.  
• AGN possibility: The compact, red central source could harbour a dust-obscured AGN; optical line ratios or X-ray data would be needed for confirmation.  
• Future evolution: Dynamical friction will bring the two nuclei together on ≲10^8 yr timescales, likely producing a bulge-dominated remnant (S0/E) with residual tidal shells.  
• Follow-up: Integral-field spectroscopy can map kinematics and metallicity to test the merger hypothesis; deep imaging would reveal the full extent of any tidal tails.
